channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl Accepted For GCI - Now We Just Need Students
item.description: The Perl Foundation was accepted to participate in the Google Code-in. Now it is time to find students between the ages 13-17 years who are interested to participate. That's where The Perl Foundation needs your help. See the post of Paul Johnson (pjcj) with details.

item.title: Famous Perl One-Liners Explained, Part VII: Handy Regular Expressions
item.description: Peteris Krumins continues his series about Perl one-liners. This time looking at regular expressions. Some of them are useful, for others there are CPAN modules that serve the purpose better than a regex.

item.title: Graphing time-based data in Perl
item.description: David Precious (bigpersh) wanted to produce some graphs for a Dancer based application. After looking around on CPAN he settled with Chart::Strip. There is a small example code and the resulting graph in the blog.

item.title: Intelligent caching for all time statistics
item.description: Sebastian Willing show how to use Memcached to keep already computed data in memory in a way that survives even a restart to the web-server.

item.title: Confident Code Using Systematic, Automated Input Validation
item.description: John Wang takes some ideas from Ruby and shows how to implement 'confident code' in Moose. It's up for discussion to figure out if this is a good or a bad way to show the power of Moose.

item.title: Technical Quality is an Insurance Policy
item.description: When you copy-paste some code, do you create 'technical debt', 'friction' or are you driving up the premium you pay for your 'technical insurance'? It's only a question of metaphor but explaining the problem in a way that is easier to understand for business people is important. Hence the article of Jeff Thalhammer on the Moder Perl Books web site.

item.title: Marpa v. Perl regexes: some numbers
item.description: Jeffrey Kegler pitches his Marpa engine against the regex engine of Perl. He says that in some cases Marpa is much faster than any regex could be. Then a discussion with Tom Christiansen makes the whole article even more interesting.

item.title: London Perl Workshop - Learning Perl Together
item.description: Ian Norton (idn) has published his slides from the 'Learning Perl Together' workshop he gave at the London Perl Workshop

item.title: Modern Core Perl Slides
item.description: Dave Cross gave a very good 90 minute long talk about what is new in Perl 5.10, 5.12, 5.14 and even in the not-yet-released 5.16. He is sharing his slides here.

item.title: Caching pages - Beyond Firebug to NYTProf
item.description: Dave Jacoby shows an example how NYTProf lead him to caching result pages reducing the response time by more than 50%. It was interesting to see now as I am planning to do the same with my simple blog engine.

item.title: Perl Tutorial: Scalar and List context in Perl, the size of an array
Slides from the Optimizing Rakudo Perl 6 talk
Fun with Perl
item.description: A couple of days ago Yitzchak Scott-Thoennes mentioned to me that the 'Fun with Perl' mailing list suddenly woke up. Judging from the archive it isn't a busy list but a very rewarding one. Assuming you like that kind of fun.

item.title: What I learned from YAPC::Brasil
item.description: brian d foy describes his experience at a conference where most of the talks are in a language he does not understand and also finds time to introduce Data::Printer. Nice pictures too.

item.title: LPW2011 : my thoughts overall
item.description: David Precious (bigpersh) reports about the London Perl Workshop.

item.title: Public Perl training in London
item.description: Dave Cross is running an 'Intermediate Perl' and an 'Advanced Perl' course in February 2012 in central London.
